info: Disclosures reference current accrued liabilities under US GAAP with a quantified amount of 353450; the chunk primarily lists tag references without narrative investor insight.

Regulatory inquiries across jurisdictions (FTC, IDPC, European Commission) with related fair value disclosures and Senior Notes, alongside equity incentive plan activity and standard US GAAP expense/tax-year data.

Meta Platforms, Inc. filed its 2024 Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2024. As of June 30, 2024, the aggregate market value of shares held by non-affiliates was 1103000000000. As of January 24, 2025, Meta reported 2189898148 shares of Class A and 343761117 shares of Class B outstanding. The principal executive office is 1 Meta Way, Menlo Park, CA 94025; the Commission file number is 35551 and the IRS Employer Identification Number is 201665019. Portions of the proxy statement for the 2025 Annual Meeting are incorporated by reference.

Meta outlines its two-segment business model (FoA and RL) with a strategic emphasis on AI, discovery, the metaverse, wearables, Threads, and monetization, while RL is expected to operate at a loss for the foreseeable future as investments scale. In 2024, FoA investments were 75250000000 and RL investments were 19880000000, with FoA representing 79 and RL 21 of total costs and expenses. In 2025, RL operating expenses are expected to be split 50/50 between wearables and metaverse initiatives. The company continues to invest in AI (including open-source Llama) and maintains a large global presence with offices in more than 90 cities. The company notes measurement challenges in Family metrics and DAP, including an estimated margin of 3% of worldwide DAP for such metrics and other potential adjustments.

Strategic emphasis on AI-driven product development and platform security, including open-source Llama models, to enhance discovery, advertising tools, and new features; ongoing technology investments, plus governance to protect privacy and integrity; broad go-to-market via self-service ads and global sales with multiple channels; large global footprint with offices in 90+ cities and a workforce of 74,067 as of December 31, 2024; subject to evolving privacy and competition regulation (GDPR, DMA/DSA, Section 230, COPPA, privacy transfers) and related potential penalties and enforcement actions.

Meta emphasizes investing in its workforce through regular performance reviews, diverse learning modalities, and programs that extend beyond traditional classrooms; it uses annual company-wide surveys and real-time daily surveys to measure sentiment and drive change. Compensation includes market-competitive salary, bonuses, and equity, with pay equity analyses showing equity across gender globally and ethnicity in the United States as of September 2024. The company highlights Life@ Meta benefits, diversity program updates in early 2025, and a commitment to reducing bias in hiring and performance management. Meta relies predominantly on advertising revenue and faces risks from user engagement fluctuations, competition (notably TikTok), data privacy and regulatory regimes (GDPR, DMA, DSA, EU AI Act, DMCC), platform integrity and security, and global operations challenges. The company cautions that adverse effects on user growth or engagement could harm revenue and financial results and notes ongoing regulatory and legal risks, as well as potential adverse publicity and evolving policies.

Regulatory and platform-shift risks are expected to pressure ad targeting, measurement, and monetization, including GDPR/ePrivacy and DMA developments, US state privacy laws, and iOS/other OS changes that reduce data signals and could dampen advertiser demand; regulatory actions in Europe over consent models and the 'subscription for no ads' option illustrate near-term monetization constraints, while heavy reliance on mobile advertising increases exposure to platform shifts. The company is investing heavily in AI and messaging with the goal of product evolution and revenue growth, but AI-related risks (safety, misinformation, regulatory scrutiny, IP, data privacy) and uncertain ROI, plus potential struggles to monetize new features (e.g., AI tools, messaging) or to realize the long-term benefits of Reality Labs, could adversely affect profitability. In addition, ongoing product changes to boost engagement (e.g., Reels vs Feed) and potential declines in user growth or engagement due to platform changes could impact near-term monetization.

Investor-relevant risks and strategic updates: product changes to feeds and ads could reduce user engagement and monetization; ongoing investments in Reality Labs (metaverse, wearables) face execution risk and uncertain ROI; brand strength and developer ecosystem face regulatory scrutiny and reputational challenges; competition from platforms that control ecosystems (e.g., Apple, Google) and evolving data/privacy rules may dampen user growth, engagement, and ad revenue; notable policy changes and scrutiny dates (Jan 2025 policy changes; scrutiny from Sep 2021; data misuse in 2018) underscore ongoing regulatory and public-relations risks.

Investor-relevant summary: The company highlights broad risks and macro factors—privacy/regulatory changes (including AI and data protection), tax and currency effects, geopolitical/tariff risks, media scrutiny, and potential litigation costs—whose mix could materially affect results. It warns that investments in AI initiatives and Reality Labs are weighing on profitability, with Reality Labs reducing 2024 operating profit by about 17.73 billion and losses expected to grow in 2025. The business remains heavily dependent on globally distributed technical infrastructure and third-party providers, exposing it to supply-chain disruptions, performance issues, and foreign government action. It also notes ongoing cost-reduction efforts and continued investment in platforms/technologies, alongside risks around measurement accuracy of ad metrics and the potential for penalties or settlements.

Metrics measurement for user geography and ad reach is uncertain due to IP/self-disclosed location methods, potential algorithmic errors, and ongoing litigation over accuracy. The company has a large international footprint with activities in about 40 countries and broad language reach, exposing it to cross-border regulatory, privacy, tax, currency, and compliance risks. The business faces hardware design, manufacturing, and supply chain risks, reliance on third parties, and inventory challenges. There is ongoing litigation risk and an active M&A strategy with integration and liquidity implications. Tax developments, including OECD BEPS considerations and a 15% global minimum tax, as well as the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, could affect future results. Past transactions such as the 2023 Giphy divestiture illustrate regulatory scrutiny in acquisitions.

Tax policy and regulatory developments could raise our worldwide effective tax rate and cash taxes; OECD and other jurisdictions are pursuing a 15% global minimum tax and digital services taxes, with transitional relief expiry and retroactive effects that could impact our financials; EU state aid investigations (including Ireland) may change tax treatment of our foreign operations; regulatory proposals to alter income tax and non-income taxes add further risk. Our 2024 tax position was affected by share-based compensation: excess tax benefits reduced our income tax provision by 3.22 billion and lowered our effective tax rate by 5 percentage points; future periods may see similar volatility. We face impairment risk for goodwill/intangible assets; governance is heavily centralized in Mark Zuckerberg, which could influence strategic decisions and shareholder value. We may not fully execute our share repurchase program or dividends; these programs depend on market conditions and could reduce cash reserves. In data/privacy regulation, evolving laws and transfer frameworks (EU-US Data Privacy Framework) and cases like the IDPC 1.2 billion euro fine create uncertainty for data transfers and service delivery; restrictions or changes in data transfer could affect ads targeting and revenue. We also note jurisdictional risks (privacy enforcement, sanctions, and geopolitical events) that could affect our operations and revenue, including in China, Hong Kong, Russia, Turkey, and other markets.

Regulatory and privacy developments across the EU, UK, U.S. and other jurisdictions create ongoing compliance costs, potential penalties, and possible restrictions on data use, advertising, and product design; ongoing FTC, EU, and other investigations and potential litigation could constrain operations and increase costs; actions related to DMA/DSA, GDPR, and data-protection and minor-rights laws are evolving, with cross-border data transfers and consent requirements affecting services; updates include launching a 'subscription for no ads' (Nov 2023 in EU/EEA/Switzerland) and offering a less personalized ads option (Nov 2024); additional considerations include potential under-16 bans in Australia by 2025. The company previously acquired Instagram (2012) and WhatsApp (2014), and faces antitrust scrutiny (FTC matters starting 2019, FTC suit 2020, EC 2024 fine) and a Texas facial-recognition settlement (2024).

Global regulatory risk from EU copyright/content liability directives and other jurisdictions, potential fines or service restrictions, evolving online content laws (DSA in EU, Online Safety Acts in UK/Ireland, and similar), and changes to Section 230 implications in the US. Payments-related regulatory exposure and CFPB rule (Larger Participant Rule) effective January 2025. Ongoing data security, privacy, and intellectual property litigation risks with potential material costs and impact on user engagement.

The chunk highlights ongoing litigation/regulatory risk, including privacy settlements and broad regulatory inquiries; the dual-class structure concentrates control with the CEO, potentially limiting investor influence; stock price has been volatile with a high/low range of 638.40 and 17.55 through 12/31/2024, and an IPO price of 38.00 in May 2012; cybersecurity risk management is emphasized but risks remain; a large real estate and data-center footprint exists (about 11 million sqft with 2 million sqft potentially subleased/abandoned, plus 62 acres); the company has 90+ offices in 90 cities and 27 data centers; a privacy settlement of 725 million was reached; governance thresholds include Class B having 10 votes per share and Class A having 1 vote per share, 9.1% control threshold, potential two-thirds voting requirements, and a 35% threshold to change control, with three-year terms under certain provisions.

Extensive privacy, regulatory, securities, and youth-safety litigation and inquiries across the U.S. and EU with material financial exposures and evolving regulatory risk. Notable items include a consumer privacy settlement of $725 million (approved Oct 2023; paid Nov 2023), a separate FTC matter with potential cost and compliance implications, and significant EU actions including a €798 million competition fine and a €1.2 billion GDPR-related fine—plus ongoing regulatory scrutiny under GDPR, the EU Data Privacy Framework, and the Digital Services Act. The company faces ongoing appeals, discovery, and trials in 2025 (e.g., DC appeal matter, New Mexico AG case, and derivative litigation), as well as potential changes to consent orders and data-transfer arrangements. Overall, substantial regulatory fines and costs, potential changes to business practices, and diversion of management resources are ongoing risks.

Meta reported 2024 revenue of 164.50 billion, up 22% YoY, with operating income of 69.38 billion; ad impressions up 11% and average price per ad up 10%. The company maintains a quarterly dividend of 0.50 per share, paid in 2024, and repurchased 29.75 billion of stock for the year, with capital expenditures of 39.23 billion and net income of 62.36 billion. However, Meta faces extensive global litigation and regulatory scrutiny (EU Digital Services Act proceedings, CFPB NORA process, and various consumer protection, data privacy, and AI-related actions) that could impact its business and strategy.

2024 highlights: net income 62.36B, diluted EPS 23.86, capex 39.23B, share repurchases 29.75B, dividends and equivalents 5.07B, cash/equivalents/securities 77.81B, long-term debt 28.83B, effective tax rate 12%, headcount 74,067 (+10% YoY). Dividends: per-share 2.00 for 2024; total dividends 4.38B (Class A) and 0.691B (Class B). Family metrics improved: DAP 3.35B average in Dec 2024 (+5% YoY); ad impressions +11%; ad price per ad +10%; ARPP 49.63 (+15% vs 2023). Advertising environment remains challenging due to regulatory/OS changes; RL investments reduced operating profit by ~17.73B in 2024 with losses expected to rise in 2025. Revenue growth by geography in 2024: US/Canada +18%, Europe +26%, Asia-Pacific +22%, Rest of World +31%.

2024 revenue reached 164.501B with operating income 69.38B and net income 62.36B. Key cost components were cost of revenue 30.161B, R&D 43.873B, marketing and sales 11.347B, and general and administrative 9.74B (total costs and expenses 95.121B). The company expects depreciation expense to fall by about 2.9B in 2025 due to extending the useful lives of servers and network assets. It also highlights ongoing contingencies, tax uncertainties, and accounting-policy considerations under GAAP.

2024 total revenue reached 164,501 million, up 22% from 2023, led by Family of Apps advertising revenue at 160,633 million and FoA total revenue of 162,355 million; Reality Labs contributed 2,146 million but RL remained loss-making with income from operations of -17,729 million. FoA operating income grew 39% to 69,380 million, driven by advertising revenue up 22% (to 160,633 million) as impressions rose 11% and average price per ad rose 10%, with offsetting higher data-center depreciation and employee costs. On a constant-currency basis, total revenue would be 165,370 million and advertising revenue 161,510 million, implying forex uplift of 874 million and 880 million respectively. Quarterly dynamics show 4Q 2024 growth of 19% versus 3Q, with 2023 and 2022 at 17% and 16% respectively, while 1Q 2024–2022 declined 9%, 11%, and 17% versus the prior fourth quarter. Costs rose across the board (cost of revenue up 16%, R&D up 14%), while Marketing and Administrative expense declined (Marketing down 8%, G&A down 15%), contributing to total operating income of 69,380 million (+48% YoY).

FoA 2024 operating income rose by 24.24B (39%) versus 2023, driven by higher advertising revenue; RL operating loss rose by 1.61B (10%), driven by higher costs and infrastructure; the company shows strong liquidity and cash flow generation, with cash and marketable securities totaling 77.81B at year-end 2024, up 12.41B from 2023, supported by 91.33B cash from operations and 10.43B net note proceeds, offset by 39.23B capex and 13.77B taxes paid related to RSU settlements; free cash flow was 52.103B. The company repurchased 65M shares for 29.75B in 2024 and has 51.28B remaining under the repurchase authorization, and paid 5.07B in dividends. Long-term debt outstanding was 29.0B; short-term and long-term debt service obligations were 1.39B and 28.10B respectively. Capex guidance for 2025 is 60-65B. The company has 9.99B of uncertain tax positions; taxes paid were 10.55B in 2024 and taxes payable at year-end were 718M. The notes provide further detail on restructuring, depreciation, and commitments as part of ongoing liquidity management.

Capital-return activity and tax/market risk context for 2024: 2024 share repurchase of 65 million Class A shares for aggregate $29.75 billion; as of December 31, 2024, $51.28 billion remained available for repurchases; the company paid four quarterly cash dividends totaling $2.00 per share (Class A and Class B) and total cash dividends and dividend equivalents paid were $5.07 billion in 2024; tax-related cash outflows included $10.55 billion in income taxes paid in 2024, with taxes payable of $718 million related to a one-time transition tax due within one year; long-term income taxes include $9.99 billion related to uncertain tax positions; the company notes loss contingencies and uncertainties that could impact results; market risks include foreign currency exchange losses of $690 million in 2024, with $366 million in 2023 and $81 million in 2022; interest-rate sensitivity indicates a hypothetical 100 basis point increase would have reduced the market value of available-for-sale debt securities by $680 million and cash equivalents by $355 million as of 2024 and 2023; fixed-rate senior notes outstanding were $29.0 billion as of 12/31/2024 and $18.5 billion as of 12/31/2023; marketable equity securities totaling $1.23 billion as of 12/31/2024 with a hypothetical 10% adverse price change of $123 million; non-marketable equity securities carrying value was $6.07 billion as of 12/31/2024 and $6.14 billion as of 12/31/2023.

Meta Platforms, Inc. received an unqualified opinion from Ernst & Young LLP on internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2024, and audited the consolidated balance sheets, statements of income, comprehensive income, stockholders' equity, and cash flows for the three years ended December 31, 2024. The internal control over financial reporting is considered effective in all material respects under COSO criteria (2013 framework). 2024 revenue was 164501 million, net income 62360 million, and comprehensive income 61418 million. The balance sheet as of 2024 shows total assets of 276054 million, total liabilities 93417 million, and stockholders' equity 182637 million. These results reflect three-year trends in revenue (2024: 164501; 2023: 134902; 2022: 116609) and key income components, illustrating robust profitability and a strong balance sheet; no internal-control deficiencies were reported.

Net income increased markedly from 2022 to 2024, reaching 62,360 in 2024; comprehensive income for 2024 was 61,418, driven by OCI components including a foreign currency translation impact of (1,413) and unrealized gains on investments of 471. Operating cash flow was 91,328 in 2024, with sizable investing and financing outflows; stock repurchases were large in 2024, and a dividend program began in 2024. Ending cash, cash equivalents, and restricted cash totaled 45,438 for 2024.

Notes highlight Meta's two reportable segments: Family of Apps (FoA) and Reality Labs (RL), with revenue recognition under ASC 606 and advertising-driven revenue; key cash-flow items include 2024 cash taxes paid of 10.554B, 2024 cash interest paid of 0.486B, and 2024 advertising expense of 2.06B; non-cash investing/financing items include PPE in accrued expenses and other current liabilities of 7.127B (2024), 4.105B (2023), and 3.319B (2022); acquisitions of businesses and intangible assets in accrued expenses and other current liabilities and other liabilities of 0.172B (2024), 0.119B (2023), and 0.291B (2022); repurchases of Class A common stock in accrued expenses and other current liabilities were 0.474B (2023) and 0.310B (2022) (2024 not disclosed); in January 2025, management extended the estimated useful lives of certain servers and network assets to 5.5 years, effective 2025.

Depreciation/impairment updates: effective January 2025, the useful life of certain servers and network assets extends to 5.5 years. The company conducts annual impairment testing for property and equipment and finite-lived intangibles; 2024–2022 net impairment losses on operating lease ROU assets and leasehold improvements were 383000000, 2430000000 and 2220000000, respectively. Deferred revenue totaled 772000000 at 12/31/2024 and 675000000 at 12/31/2023, with 721000000 expected to be realized within one year. 2024 total revenue was 164501000000, with major contribution from Advertising (160633000000) and Family of Apps (162355000000) and Reality Labs (2146000000). Revenue by geography for 2024: United States and Canada 63207000000, Europe 38361000000, Asia-Pacific 45009000000, Rest of World 17924000000. US revenue in 2024 was 59730000000 and China revenue 18350000000. The company recognized 2022 restructuring charges totaling 4611000000 across all categories, with 2024 restructuring charges of 389000000 related to facilities consolidation. Note that the 2022 restructuring was completed by 2024.

Restructuring activity in 2024–2022 includes significant facilities consolidation; 2024 pre-tax charges totaled 389 million, 2023 2,255 million, 2022 4,611 million. The 2024 plan-to-date breakdown shows Facilities Consolidation 5,190 million, Severance and Other Personnel Costs 948 million, Data Center Assets 1,116 million, for a total of 7,254 million. By segment, FoA restructuring totals were 305 million (2024), 1,740 million (2023), 4,100 million (2022); RL totals were 84 million, 516 million, 515 million. The 2023 restructuring charges for severance were 1.20 billion and the 2023 restructuring was completed as of December 31, 2023.

Unrealized losses on available-for-sale marketable debt securities are disclosed for 2024 and 2023, by security type and loss duration. Total unrealized losses declined in 2024 to $481 million from $934 million in 2023, while total fair value increased to $23,070 million from $21,445 million.

Goodwill and intangibles are substantial and largely stable, with total goodwill at 20,654 million as of both 2023 and 2024. A major debt program was completed in 2024 adding 10.5 billion in notes. The company carries a large long-term debt load (28.826 billion ending 2024 vs 18.385 billion ending 2023) and holds a significant non-cancelable contractual commitments base (32.824 billion). Renewable energy spend commitments total about 24.97 billion. Amortization and impairment schedules for finite-lived intangibles indicate continued near-term expense (amortization expense 211, 161, 185 million for 2024, 2023, 2022 respectively) with forecast amortization totaling 490 million over the next five years and thereafter. Accrued expenses contain large legal accruals and other liabilities, underscoring ongoing liquidity considerations. Overall, leverage, large contractual commitments, and ongoing amortization/claims risk are notable investor considerations.

Extensive global legal and regulatory exposure across privacy/data practices, competition, securities, and youth-safety matters. Notable outcomes include a $725M privacy settlement (court-approved Oct 10, 2023; payment in Nov 2023), a $5.0B FTC penalty under the modified consent order, and GDPR/IDPC penalties including a €1.2B fine (Final Decision May 12, 2023) and an EU antitrust fine of about €798M (Dec 2024). Several matters are ongoing with 2025 trial/hearing dates and court/appeal activity (e.g., DC cases with hearings in early 2025 and NM trial scheduled for Dec 1, 2025; FTC threshold issues decision on Jan 10, 2025; appeal activity in early 2025). The company accrues losses when losses are probable and estimable and has accrued significant amounts for loss contingencies in Europe; there is a reasonable possibility that additional accruals could be material individually or in the aggregate. Outcomes and enforcement are uncertain and may lead to modifications to orders or further proceedings; the company is vigorously defending regulatory compliance.

Regulatory and litigation updates affecting Facebook/Instagram, including adolescent safety actions, COPPA and child-safety concerns, EU Digital Services Act proceedings, CFPB NORA process, and ongoing advertising-related actions; plus financial measures on stock repurchases, dividends, RSU program, and tax metrics for 2024.

Tax position and operational update: material ongoing tax examinations (US IRS for 2017–2019, 2020 and later years; Irish authorities for 2020 and later years) with potential additional federal tax liability up to about $9.0 billion if transfer pricing positions prevail; separate prior notices and ongoing Tax Court actions could also yield up to about $680 million in related liabilities. Substantial deferred tax assets and liabilities exist, with net deferred tax assets of $9.578 billion as of 2024 and net of valuation allowance $23.537 billion; gross deferred tax assets $27.043 billion and a valuation allowance of $3.506 billion. As of 12/31/2024, state net operating loss carryforwards total $2.36 billion, federal tax credits total $0.595 billion, and state tax credits total $5.47 billion (most do not expire). Unrecognized tax benefits remain significant ($15.131 billion end of 2024), with interest/penalties noted. On the operational side, two segments (FoA and RL) show robust Family of Apps profitability ($69.38B operating income on $164.501B revenue in 2024) while Reality Labs remains loss-making; total company revenue of $164.501B in 2024 with total operating income of $69.38B. Long-lived assets are heavily invested in the United States ($117.478B) and rest of world ($18.79B) for a total of $136.268B as of 12/31/2024. These items imply substantial tax planning considerations and ongoing risk management alongside strong revenue growth in FoA.

Geographic long-lived assets dominated by United States; 2024 US assets about 117.478B and Rest of World about 18.79B, totaling 136.268B, up from 109.881B in 2023. No single non-disclosed country exceeded 10% of total assets.

Exhibit list shows governance and compensation disclosures, including amendments to the 2012 Equity Incentive Plan, multiple award agreements, executive and director compensation letters, and related-party arrangements (e.g., Mark Zuckerberg aircraft time-sharing). Also includes governance exhibits such as insider trading policy, trading plan policy, subsidiaries, and auditor consent.
